title: Deacon Jones (infielder)
text:
Grover William "Deacon" Jones (born April 18, 1934) is a retired <a href="Americans">American</a> <a href="professional%20baseball">professional baseball</a> <a href="baseball%20player">player</a>, <a href="coach%20%28baseball%29">coach</a>, <a href="manager%20%28baseball%29">manager</a> and <a href="scout%20%28sport%29">scout</a>. He appeared in 40 <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball">Major League</a> <a href="games%20played">games</a> as a <a href="first%20baseman">first baseman</a> and <a href="pinch%20hitter">pinch hitter</a> for the <a href="Chicago%20White%20Sox">Chicago White Sox</a> (1962–63; 1966). Jones attended <a href="Ithaca%20College">Ithaca College</a>, threw right-handed, batted left-handed and was listed as tall and .
In his 11-year minor-league career (1955–56; 1959–67; 1969), Jones with 154 <a href="home%20runs">home runs</a> and a <a href="slugging%20percentage">slugging percentage</a> . His big-league experience consisted of 60 plate appearances and he (14 <a href="hit%20%28baseball%29">hits</a> in 49 <a href="at%20bats">at bats</a>) with one home run (hit off <a href="Jim%20Hannan">Jim Hannan</a> of the <a href="Washington%20Senators%20%281961%E2%80%9371%29">Washington Senators</a> on September 28, 1963) and 10 <a href="runs%20batted%20in">runs batted in</a>. A great natural hitter, Jones still holds the <a href="Midwest%20League">Midwest League</a> record for the highest single-season batting average when he for the <a href="Dubuque%20Packers">Dubuque Packers</a> in 1956. He also had 135 hits, smashed 26 homers and had slugging percentage in only 330 at bats.
After retiring as a player, Jones served as a scout and <a href="minor%20league%20baseball">minor-league</a> coach and manager in the White Sox organization through 1973. Jones was a coach for the <a href="Houston%20Astros">Houston Astros</a> from 1976–82, and with the <a href="San%20Diego%20Padres">San Diego Padres</a> from 1984–87. Jones joined the <a href="Baltimore%20Orioles">Baltimore Orioles</a> as a minor-league hitting coach and liaison with minority communities.
Jones is currently serving as the special assistant to the president for the <a href="Sugar%20Land%20Skeeters">Sugar Land Skeeters</a>, a member of the independent <a href="Atlantic%20League%20of%20Professional%20Baseball">Atlantic League of Professional Baseball</a>.
